HomePage.anumoAbout: We are a design studio of objects made from recycled plastic. Established in 2020 in Kyiv. We explore the possibilities of plastic recycling and reuse, transforming it into unique accessories and interior items

material.title: MATERIAL
material.description: HDPE plastic (bottles from detergents, cosmetics, or baby food).

production.title: PRODUCTION
production.description: 80% hand-made / 20% work with technical equipment: thermal press, extruder, and additional electrical tools.

inspiration.title: INSPIRATION
inspiration.description: We draw inspiration from colors and always pay special attention to selecting materials and color combinations using collage techniques. This results in our products having unique patterns and a recognizable style.

values.title: VALUES
values.description:
We demonstrate that eco-consciousness and creativity are sustainable solutions in the fight for a clean environment. Plastic recycling has great potential and allows us to create quality functional items that provide aesthetic satisfaction while conserving our planet’s resources.

We advocate for open and honest cooperation, built on horizontal hierarchy and principles of mutual respect. We do not support exploitation or product testing on animals. We do not cooperate with terrorist countries.

ukrainianCeramics.title: UKRAINIAN CERAMICS:JUG AND POTS FROM BIOMATERIAL
ukrainianCeramics.description:
These jug and pots are the result of research into the history of Ukrainian ceramics and the development of its technologies.

In this project we rethink the technology of ceramics, using 3D printing technology and materials of natural origin: starch, miscanthus, and vegetable wax. This combination gives space for reflection on the possibilities of using uncommon materials in everyday life, as well as recycling materials for a more ecological and harmonious existence in the world.

Vases appear in sustained pastel colors that remind us of the colors of Ukraine -  the color of clay and the mown grass.

Patterns on jugs and pots have natural motifs: flowers, a sown field (a sign of fertility), and wicker reeds.

The project is designed to explore Ukrainian culture and introduce it to the audience.

During the Russian-Ukrainian full-scale war, when people from other countries learn about Ukraine from photos of destroyed cities and killed people, it is vital to show the other side of Ukraine - its culture.

tableIvan.title: TABLE IVAN
tableIvan.description: The transformation of plastic under the influence of Ukrainian crafts
tableIvan.description_1:
The «Ivan» project was born from a chance encounter with a photograph of an antique chair from the Ivan Honchar Museum. The chair’s unique design and natural motifs caught our attention. Though its creator remains unknown, the chair, separated from the museum’s main collection, became a profound source of inspiration for us.

Using the forms of this historic chair as the foundation, we crafted a unique table named Ivan, honoring the renowned Ukrainian artist and collector Ivan Honchar. While Honchar and other craftsmen worked with traditional materials like clay and wood, at our studio, Anumo, we explore the potential of plastic bottles—typically viewed as waste. To us, this material is a contemporary resource full of possibilities.

Our research focuses on pushing the boundaries of what plastic can achieve. Inspired by traditional woodcarving techniques, we adapted these methods for plastic. Using a rotary tool, we created intricate grooves on the tabletop, giving it a tactile, three-dimensional texture.

The table legs feature a monochrome color palette and echo the contours of the tabletop, embodying naive, natural motifs. In contrast to the understated legs, the tabletop is composed of numerous colorful detergent bottles, resulting in a vivid, dynamic surface.

With its form and vibrant patterns, the table bridges the gap between modernity and antiquity. We embrace eclecticism—a hallmark of our culture and everyday life—fearlessly blending diverse elements.

The Ivan project is our manifesto for sustainable design and a celebration of creative experimentation. It embodies our exploration of Ukrainian culture and plastic recycling, demonstrating how waste can be transformed into new, functional, and aesthetically pleasing objects without harming the environment.

Ivan The Table was developed in collaboration with 22fworks Studio.
